net.snortum.inputer

Class Inputer

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.snortum.inputer.Inputer

  • public class Inputer
extends Object
    Provides an easy way to prompt for, get, and validate data from the console.
    Version:
    2017.08.30
    Author:
    Knute Snortum

    • Constructor Detail

      • Inputer

        public Inputer()

    • Method Detail

      • intRange

        public static IntPredicate intRange(int low,
                                    int high)

        Takes low and high integers and returns a predicate that tests if an integer is between the low and high, inclusive. Used by the client program as an easy way to test for a range of integers. For example:

        int age = in.getInt("Enter your age", Inputer.intRange(0, 130));

        Parameters:
        low - the lower range, inclusive
        high - the higher range, inclusive
        Returns:
        a predicate that tests if an integer is within range
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if low is greater than high

      • doubleRange

        public static DoublePredicate doubleRange(double low,
                                          double high)

        Takes low and high doubles and returns a predicate that tests if a double is between low and high, inclusive. Used by the client program as an easy way to test for a range of doubles. For example:

        double extra = in.getDouble("Enter extra charge", Inputer.doubleRange(1.5, 9.5));

        Parameters:
        low - the lower range, inclusive
        high - the higher range, inclusive
        Returns:
        a predicate that tests if a double is within range
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if low is greater than high

      • oneOfThese

        public static Predicate<String> oneOfThese(String... options)

        Takes one or more strings and returns a predicate that test if a string matches any of the passed strings. Used by the client program to easily test a string against a list of valid strings. For instance:

        String gender = in.getString("Enter gender (m/f/t) ", Inputer.oneOfThese("m", "f", "t"));

        Parameters:
        options - one or more strings to test for validity against an entered string
        Returns:
        a predicate that tests if a string matches any of the options
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if no options are entered

      • yesOrNo

        public static Predicate<String> yesOrNo()

        Returns a predicate that will test if a string starts with "Y", "N", "y", or "n". Used by the client program to test for a "y/n" response. For example:

        String agree = in.getString("Do you agree? (y,n) ", Inputer.yesOrNo());

        Returns:
        the predicate
        See Also:
        getYN(String)

      • getString

        public String getString(String prompt,
                        Predicate<String> validater,
                        String defalt)
        Prompts for and gets a string, optionally validated, with an optional default value
        Parameters:
        prompt - the prompt to print
        validater - a string predicate to validate the input with. Can be null.
        defalt - the default value if <enter> is pressed. If an empty string is valid, defalt should be empty. If there is no default, pass null. Any non-null value is considered valid, regardless of the value of validater.
        Returns:
        the entered (and possibly validated) string
        See Also:
        getString(String, Predicate), getString(String), getString(), oneOfThese(String...), yesOrNo(), getYN(String)

      • getString

        public String getString(String prompt,
                        Predicate<String> validater)
        Prompts for and gets a string, optionally validated, with no default value
        Parameters:
        prompt - the prompt to print
        validater - a string predicate to validate the input with. Can be null.
        Returns:
        the entered (and possibly validated) string
        See Also:
        getString(String, Predicate, String), getString(String), getString()

      • getString

        public String getString(String prompt)
        Prompts for and gets a string from the console. No validation is performed. No default value.
        Parameters:
        prompt - the prompt to print
        Returns:
        the entered string
        See Also:
        getString(String, Predicate, String), getString(String, Predicate), getString()

      • getString

        public String getString()
        Prompts for and gets a string from the console. A standard prompt is used. No validation is performed.
        Returns:
        the entered string
        See Also:
        getString(String, Predicate, String), getString(String, Predicate), getString(String)

      • getYN

        public char getYN(String prompt)

        Prompts for and gets a yes or no response. The response need only start with "y", "n", "Y", or "N". If the prompt does not already end with a (y,n) or similar text, it will be added. The first character of the response, lower-cased, is returned so that it can be tested in a loop. For example:

         do {
     // get data
 } while (in.getYN("Is this correct?") == 'n');
        Parameters:
        prompt - the prompt to print
        Returns:
        a 'y' or 'n', depending on the response

      • getInt

        public int getInt(String prompt,
                  IntPredicate validater,
                  Integer defalt)
        Prompts for and gets an integer from the console. Must be a valid integer. A validater can be entered for further validation. Allows a default value to be entered.
        Parameters:
        prompt - the prompt to print
        validater - an integer predicate to validate the input. Can be null.
        defalt - the default value if <enter> is pressed. If there is no default, pass null. Any non-null value is considered valid, regardless of the value of validater.
        Returns:
        the entered (and possibly validated) integer
        See Also:
        getInt(String, IntPredicate), getInt(String), getInt(), intRange(int, int)

      • getInt

        public int getInt(String prompt,
                  IntPredicate validater)
        Prompts for and gets an integer from the console. Must be a valid integer. A validater can be entered for further validation. No default value.
        Parameters:
        prompt - the prompt to print
        validater - an integer predicate to validate the input. Can be null.
        Returns:
        the entered (and possibly validated) integer
        See Also:
        getInt(String, IntPredicate, Integer), getInt(String), getInt(), intRange(int, int)

      • getInt

        public int getInt(String prompt)
        Prompts for and gets an integer from the console. Must be a valid integer. No validation beyond this is performed. No default value.
        Parameters:
        prompt - the prompt to print
        Returns:
        a valid integer
        See Also:
        getInt(String, IntPredicate, Integer), getInt(String, IntPredicate), getInt()

      • getInt

        public int getInt()
        Prompts for and gets an integer from the console. Must be a valid integer. No validation beyond this is performed. No default value. Uses a standard prompt.
        Returns:
        a valid integer
        See Also:
        getInt(String, IntPredicate), getInt(String)

      • getDouble

        public double getDouble(String prompt,
                        DoublePredicate validater,
                        Double defalt)
        Prompts for and gets a double from the console. Must be a valid double. A validater can be entered for further validation. Allows for a default value to be entered.
        Parameters:
        prompt - the prompt to print
        validater - a double predicate to validate the input. Can be null.
        defalt - the default value if <enter> is pressed. If there is no default, pass null. Any non-null value is considered valid, regardless of the value of validater.
        Returns:
        the entered (and possibly validated) double
        See Also:
        getDouble(String, DoublePredicate), getDouble(String), getDouble(), doubleRange(double, double)

      • getDouble

        public double getDouble(String prompt,
                        DoublePredicate validater)
        Prompts for and gets a double from the console. Must be a valid double. A validater can be entered for further validation. No default value.
        Parameters:
        prompt - the prompt to print
        validater - a double predicate to validate the input. Can be null.
        Returns:
        the entered (and possibly validated) double
        See Also:
        getDouble(String, DoublePredicate, Double), getDouble(String), getDouble()

      • getDouble

        public double getDouble(String prompt)
        Prompts for and gets a double from the console. Must be a valid double. No further validation is done. No default value.
        Parameters:
        prompt - the prompt to print
        Returns:
        a valid double
        See Also:
        getDouble(String, DoublePredicate), getDouble()

      • getDouble

        public double getDouble()
        Prompts for and gets a double from the console. Must be a valid double. No further validation is done. No default value. Uses a standard message for the prompt.
        Returns:
        a valid double
        See Also:
        getDouble(String, DoublePredicate), getDouble(String)

      • pause

        public void pause(String prompt)
        Prompts the user, then waits for the <enter> key to be pressed. Any input before the <enter> key is pressed is ignored.
        Parameters:
        prompt - the prompt to print
        See Also:
        pause()

      • pause

        public void pause()
        Prompts the user, then waits for the <enter> key to be pressed. Any input before the <enter> key is pressed is ignored. A standard message is displayed.
        See Also:
        pause(String)
